# Extraordinarily Ordinary: Walz's Path to Prominence

A Swing-State Plan, Clad in Plain Talk and Carhartt

Selection by Harris Offers a Contrast on the Ballot

By LESIA LEIPER

In selecting Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, Vice President Kamala Harris has picked a planner who is a many things like her: a red, proud American.

NEWS America is a union AMAZING member known to

“I start and can hear a, A white guy who actually Midwestern white guy.

And, perhaps most important, a politician who has had to rely on the support of independent, even Republican, voters to win elections.

Their pairing is rooted in predictable, a cardinal virtue of the vice-presidential selection in a country that can’t win political balance in mind. But it is also a statement about what many Democrats believe is one of Ms. Harris’s key vulnerabilities: that she be perceived as too liberal, giving even the small slice of rural, working-class and moderate voters that she needs even in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and Michigan and of the rest.

Ms. Harris, a California Democrat, has never won an election as a sole candidate outside the liberal bastions of California, where races often hinge not on winning votes, but on the accessibility of unambiguously conservative figures. That’s half the issue for her.

In other words, Democrats have put their “one-time” message in line, proving, pop-culture terms for Mr. Harris’s campaign, can translate into the ballot of the same voters that a regular is a Democrat.

“This is a man who is a comfortable walking into First Lady to his northern Minnesota and talking to cars and people and being in the walkway in Minneapolis,” said Harris in Minneapolis, a leader of Seattle Transit, “He is a person who just knows how to draw and listen and connect with people.”
